title: yasuo's windwall broken?
body:
I'm not arguing that yasuo shouldn't have a windwall. I think that's fine.

But I was playing blitzcrank, i threw a hook, he panicked and threw his windwall at a 90 degree angle from where my hook was coming from... and it blocked the pull.

I think we have to question whether his windwall is too forgiving when used improperly.

Also, why the hell does the windwall block from both ways? that's a separate issue, but still worth talking about

replies.body: Can we first address the issue of hook champions missing you by 200 units but the skill snaps to you anyways?

So what happens when you drop Wind Wall to protect your ADC as they kite back, and the enemy team walks past Wind Wall? Right I forgot, everyone just stands still during teamfights and never reposition. Also:

Unbreakable duration: 3 / 3.25 / 3.5 / 3.75 / 4

Wind Wall: The wall slowly drifts forward over 3.75 seconds

?

They can't fire any attacks as you move back or fire any skillshots. By the time they walk past it the duration is most likely over or near over. If they're walking past the windwall they can just as easily move 30 degrees to the left/right and get the ADC where the shield isn't facing. So re-positioning doesn't really matter either way. 

"The gust of wind takes ~0.25 seconds to travel forward from Yasuo to form the wall, but will still block projectiles as with the fully formed wall during that time (for a total of 4 seconds as listed in the in-game tooltip)." So Windwall does last longer and blocks more damage every single rank until the last rank, where it breaks even in duration. 

It also has a range of 400, meaning he doesn't have to be in front of the ally to protect them. He can be behind them, even. It also increases in width up to 500 (a rank 2 Anivia wall for comparison.) 

It also protects against more attacks than Braum, though both only protect against projectiles. 

Yasuo's windwall is the better shield by far. Which is why it has 3x the cooldown.

* That still isn't longer, both are 4 seconds. Unbreakable is also maxed second, while Wind Wall is maxed last.
* Braum's shield reduces/blocks **all** damage, not just projectiles. If you walk up and crit Yasuo for 900 damage as Tryndamere, he dies
* I don't know what kind of teamfights you're in where it takes 4 seconds for someone to dive an ADC, but its an awful one
* Braum then walks sideways and continues blocking. Not only that, but the ADC is gaining distance as you walk at an angle, peeling yourself. Braum also gets 10% bonus movespeed to reposition faster than you
* Braum is supposed to be in front of his teammates, while Yasuo is supposed to be on the enemy backline, so I don't really know what you're on about here. The only time Yasuo will be behind is carry is while he's fleeing, and that again means you'll be past Wind Wall in about 2 seconds, wasting his 26 second cooldown

* Unbreakable is maxed first/second because it needs to be. Windwall is maxed last because it's a one-point wonder ability. You only need one point in it. 
* Sorry if I was unclear, I'm talking about protecting another player, not yourself. The shield only intercepts projectiles. If Tryndamere walks up and crits your ADC for 900 damage, he's dead. It doesn't matter if there was a Braum shield or a windwall. Both only protect against projectiles. 
* If someone is using projectiles they don't usually dive the ADC, they'll use them from a distance. Or rather, they'll already be at that distance when they are using the projectile such as a Jinx or Lux ult. If they are diving into your team, such as a Rengar, a windwall wouldn't do much. 
* Braum can do that, I'm just saying if someone would get past a windwall, they'd more than likely also get past Braum's shield. My point was comparing their work-around isn't really saying much because they can both be worked around.
* If everybody is low HP and fleeing, then you see a red laser of death from Lux you can throw it out while ahead of your team and continue running. Anyway, it wasn't really about the positioning in the slightest. It was more about how his has range and Braum's doesn't. 

I'm not saying Yasuo needs a nerf or Braum needs a buff, but it's pretty obvious who has the better shield here lol.
So lemme get this straight, you're playing a full tank, and complaining about having to stand in front of your ADC and soak damage...

Well, why the melee carry has a better shield than the full tank, or honestly pretty much EVERY support in the game, is something worth mentioning.  People just sorta excuse Yasuo for this stuff, but why does he get to have such an incredibly potent defensive power?  Most supports would KILL for wind wall.  Why does the spastic carry get it?

Also, why is Yasuo allowed to literally stand inside his windwall to be immune to the adc for 4 seconds?  Why does it block spells that are cast BEHIND him if he panic-casts it at the right time?  Why is he able to swing a fight so hard in his team's favor with a single wind wall or by pressing R after his initiator goes in... even if he's massively behind?  

Change Wind Wall or get rid of it and you will see the hate for Yasuo disappear overnight.  It's at least 70% of the reason he's so frustrating to play against.
You would also see his winrate drop from sub 50 to sub 30 or 20

The main reason for an assassin winning games should be sourced around Assassin like skill shouldn't it? Like how a tank should be getting wins for their ability to tank, a support for their ability to set up plays, assist allies, etc. Honestly, Wind wall makes more sense on Janna. Even Jax's defensive ability only protects him and only from autos while still actually making a contribution to his combat with a stun. Yasuo should have something that aids in locking down a kill not running when you make a stupid play.

From what I understand the wall is created from within Yasuo then moves out slightly in front of him. This allows him to knee jerk cast it in any direction as a projectile is about to hit him and it will always block.

What Riot SHOULD do is start the Windwall creation in front of Yasuo, so it's never 100% encompassing his body from all directions. It's supposed to be a WALL not a DOME.

Xerath's Q is a beam, not a bullet.
Same with lux ult, Viktor's Q2, and Azir's AA.
Viktor E goes through, right?

No. His E is considered a bullet.
His E2, however, is not. But it follows the path E1 took start to finish.
So if E hits windwall, E2 will stop where windwall deleted it. If windwall is cast *after* E, E2 will be unaffected.
The reason it goes through is because the effect happens instantly with no travel time, so it isn't considered a projectile.

The wall blocking projectiles from both sides is the whole point of the design. It's not even a problem since your blitz hook probably came off cooldown before his windwall anyways.
